legal_basis.law: 犯罪による収益の移転防止に関する法律
legal_basis.law_en: Act on Prevention of Transfer of Criminal Proceeds (Anti-Money Laundering)
legal_basis.deadline_description_en: No legal deadline, but needed almost immediately for salary, rent, and utilities
legal_basis.penalty_en: None for not opening an account, but daily life in Japan is extremely difficult without one
legal_basis.cost_note_en: Free to open. ATM and transfer fees vary by bank.

eligibility.residence_requirement_en: Most banks: 6+ months of residence in Japan. Exception: Japan Post Bank accepts 3+ months.
eligibility.visa_requirement_en: Must hold a valid residence status (在留資格) with a period of stay over 6 months on your Residence Card.
exceptions: Japan Post Bank (ゆうちょ銀行): Only requires 3+ months on Residence Card. Most accessible for newcomers.
Employer-sponsored: If your employer banks with MUFG/SMBC/Mizuho, they may help you open an account before the 6-month mark.
Some online banks (Seven Bank, Rakuten) have streamlined processes but still need 6 months.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Going to a megabank within your first 6 months
common_mistakes.fix_en: Start with Japan Post Bank — they accept 3+ month residence. Open a megabank account later if needed.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Writing name in romaji instead of katakana on the form
common_mistakes.fix_en: Your account name MUST be in katakana. Practice writing your name beforehand or ask staff for help.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Not having a Japanese phone number
common_mistakes.fix_en: Get a prepaid SIM first (available at convenience stores and electronics shops with just a passport). Banks need to call or SMS you.
Banks are required to ask why you need the account (anti-money laundering). Say '給与受取と生活費' (salary and living expenses) — concrete and normal.

Japanese systems expect exactly two names (surname + given). If you have middle names, you may need to omit them or combine them with your first name. Make sure your bank name matches your Residence Card name exactly.
Bank branch counters close at 3 PM sharp (some at 4 PM). Arrive by 2 PM latest to allow time for processing.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Not bringing both Residence Card AND passport
common_mistakes.fix_en: Some branches want both even if the website says one is enough. Bring everything to avoid a wasted trip.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Choosing a birthday as your PIN
common_mistakes.fix_en: Banks may reject PINs that match your birthday, phone number, or sequential numbers (1234). Pick something unrelated.

middle_name_guide.explanation_en: Japanese name systems expect exactly one surname and one given name. Most banking systems have character limits (often 20-30 katakana) and no concept of middle names. This causes real problems for people with long or multi-part names.

options.option_en: Combine first + middle as one given name
options.example: John Michael Smith → ジョン マイケル スミス or ジョンマイケル スミス
options.note: Most common approach. Must match your Residence Card.

options.example: John Michael Smith → ジョン スミス
options.note: Only if your Residence Card also shows it this way. May need to register a 通称 (alias) at city hall.

options.option_en: Register a legal alias (通称, tsūshō)
options.example: Go to your ward office with supporting documents (employment certificate, etc.)
options.note: Cleanest long-term solution. Your alias appears on Residence Card, My Number, and bank records.
